clinical_study.brief_title: Mild Hypothermia Influence on Patient Outcome in Major Abdominal Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Does Mild Hypothermia Increase Intra-Operative Blood Loss and Surgical Site Infections in Major Abdominal Surgery?

brief_summary.textblock: This study investigate associations between mild hypothermia (patients' core temperature â‰¤ 36.0 degrees Celsius) and intra-operative blood loss and surgical site infections (SSI) in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study evaluates associations between patients' core temperature during surgery and intra-operative blood loss, and to SSI. Additionally, the investigators observe the use of hypothermia prevention measures in operating theaters, use of surgical safety checklists. SSI is registered at discharge from hospital and up to 30 days post-discharge.
The goal of the study is to contribute to focus on prevention of even mild hypothermia in surgery.
This study is of interest for healthcare personnel as operating room nurses, surgeons, nurse anaesthetists, anaesthesiologists, ward nurses, post anaesthetic care unit nurses, and other healthcare staff involved in the in-hospital surgical pathway.

primary_outcome.measure: Intra-operative blood loss (mL) in surgical patients
primary_outcome.description: Bleeding that occur during the surgical procedure

secondary_outcome.measure: Peri-operative blood loss (registered by ICD-10 codes)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Within the duration of the surgical procedures, an average of 2.5 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with Surgical Site Infections after surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 30 days after discharge from hospital
secondary_outcome.description: Post-operative surgical site infections present before discharge from hospital

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with Surgical Site Infection
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 30 days after discharge from hospital
secondary_outcome.description: Post-operative surgical site infection present after discharge from hospital

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Hospital stay up to 13 days on average

secondary_outcome.measure: Hours admitted in post operative care unit (PACU)

arm_group.description: Patients with mild hypothermia at start of the surgery
Patients with normal core temperature at start of surgery.

intervention.description: Patients are routinely warmed with forced air warming blankets, regular blankets, pre warmed intravenous fluid. Routines are ensured with use of the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist. The intervention is the use of operating theatre care measures to prevent mild hypothermia in surgical patients.

study_pop.textblock: The study population consist of patients undergoing abdominal or gynecologic laparatomy or laparoscopy in a tertiary teaching hospital in Norway.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients (men or women) above 18 years, undergoing abdominal or gynecological surgery with laparotomy or laparoscopy.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Surgical procedures with intentional reduction of core temperature. Patients under the age of 18.
